raw_extractions.role: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
raw_extractions.description: First woman, first academic, and first Japanese person to hold this position. Led efforts in Iraq, the Balkans, Africa’s Great Lakes region, and Afghanistan.
supporting_quotes: As the first woman, the first academic and the first Japanese person to serve as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, Ogata led the UN Refugee Agency’s efforts in Iraq, the Balkans, Africa’s Great Lakes region and Afghanistan.

raw_extractions.description: First president of the $16 billion organization affiliated with Japan’s Foreign Ministry, charged with building ties in the Asia-Pacific region.
supporting_quotes: Closer to home, she was the first president of the $16 billion Japan International Cooperation Agency, an organization affiliated with Japan’s Foreign Ministry charged with building ties in the Asia-Pacific region, outside of U.S.’s long shadow.

Born into a family of politicians and diplomats who have played roles at crucial turning points in 20th-century Japan, Ogata continued the tradition — first as a scholar and then as practitioner of international relations — in a new global context.

My book is a social biography of Japan’s best-known international leader of the late 20th century, the diplomat Sadako Ogata (1927–2019). In telling her life story, I analyze the factors that facilitated her professional success, as a scholar of international relations, as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), and as president
of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), which is the organization that distributes Japan’s foreign aid.
